Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description:
Electrical insulators are commonly recognized as materials that prevent the flow of electricity. However, recent research demonstrates a type of topological insulators which has novel properties. Although electricity cannot flow through them, it can flow around their narrow outer edges. The material, called a "quantum spin Hall topological insulator", acts as an electron superhighway. It is one of the building blocks needed to create future electronics and computers. In this project the principle investigator will perform experiments on the newly discovered topological insulators made of compound semiconductors indium arsenide and gallium antimonide, addressing important issues relate to materials science and quantum physics. Understanding of materials science of this class of material and their topological properties is directly relevant to spintronics and quantum information technology.

Technical descripton:
The two-dimensional topological insulator, which supports quantized helical edge modes, is created by band-gap engineering using molecular beam epitaxy and electrostatic gates. The project is exploring interesting physics at the messoscopic length scale, with the focus on the helical edge modes and their interface with superconductors, where proximity effect and Andreev reflection are being systematically studied. Major focus of the study is searching for Majorana bound states in hybrid topological insulator-superconductor Josephson junctions. The experimental research work addresses fundamental phenomenon and its physics in a very clean model system. The project supports the education of two Ph.D. students, where they receive a combination of advanced training in semiconductor materials, nanotechnology, and ultra-low temperature measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Topology and electronic correlations play important roles in shaping the physical properties of quantum materials. This project has centered on the studies of a model system consisting of Coulomb-coupled, spatially separated electron and hole double layers, confined in semiconductor compounds InAs (for electrons) and GaSb (holes). In previous work the PIs group discovered the quantum Spin Hall effect in this system. Owning to a special topology of the conduction and valence bands, where their order in terms of energy is reversed as compared to normal materials, two-dimensional (2D) bulk of the double layer becomes an insulator which prevents the flow of electricity. Remarkably, electricity can instead flow in its perimeters through edge channels. Because of the protection from topology and symmetry the electrical current can flow without dissipating power. Such property can be harnessed for developing a new generation of electronics and quantum computers.

This project has focused on the investigations on electronic correlation effects, concerning the emergent properties of electron-hole double layers. Here the transport properties of the edge channel cannot be understood by a single-particle picture, but must by taking into account the correlation of electrons which are moving together coherently in a dance pattern [1]. This property, which is referred to as helical Luttinger liquid transport, has been predicted by theories but has only been recently confirmed by experiments (Figure 1 & 2). The results underscore the strong electron-electron interaction effect in transport of InAs/GaSb edge channels. 

Another major finding concerns the correlation effect between the electrons and the holes, which are coupled by strong Coulomb interactions (see Figure 3). It is well known that, theoretically, electron-hole pairing can occur in a dilute semimetal, transforming the system into an excitonic insulator state in which a gap spontaneously appears at the Fermi surface, analogous to a Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer (BCS) superconductor. Optical spectroscopic and electronic transport evidences have been observed for the formation of an excitonic insulator gap in the bilayers at low temperatures and low electron-hole densities [2]. Terahertz transmission spectra exhibit two absorption lines that are quantitatively consistent with predictions from the pair-breaking excitation dispersion calculated based on the BCS gap equation (see Figure 4). Low-temperature electronic transport measurements reveal a critical temperature of ~10 Kelvin in the 2D bulk, together with quantized edge conductance, suggesting the occurrence of a topological excitonic insulator phase.

Both the helical Luttinger liquid and the topological excitonic insulator are new states of matter emerging from the topological structure of the hosting material as well as the electronic correlation. It is reasonable to anticipate yet unknown quantum phases to be discovered in this system [3]. 

Intellectual Merit: This project has focused on the studies of electronic correlation effects in the newly discovered InAs/GaSb topological insulator, which can be atomically controlled by molecular beam epitaxy band-gap engineering. Additional quantum control using electrostatic gates were demonstrated. The work  continued to explore interesting physics; major findings are the observations on the helical Luttinger liquid transport in edge states, and the realization of topological excitonic insulator in dilute double layers. The research is path-finding and potentially transformative (for example in the area of topological quantum computing). This experimental research addresses the fundamental phenomena and the physics in a very clean model system; what being learned from it can impact many branches of physics. By combining with superconductors the quantum spin Hall double layer may prove to be a viable platform for realizing Majorana fermion zero modes, which can be utilized for constructing topological Qubits.

Broader Impacts: Understanding of fundamental properties of a two-dimensional electron-hole system, and their topological and correlation properties is directly relevant to spintronic devices and quantum information processing. Improvement of material quality, invention of new materials and structures, and characterization of structures are the activities that are of direct impact for novel devices (for example the electron-hole injection laser). The research in this model system has already shown impact to other materials such as 2D atomic layers in the investigation of quantum spin Hall effect and excitonic condensations. Finally, education of students familiar with semiconductor physics, nanoscale fabrication, and low temperature quantum transport serves well for high-technology industry. This project also builds on a successful academy-industrial collaboration.
